title: Effectiveness of protected areas for vertebrates based on taxonomic and phylogenetic diversity

abstract: Establishing protected areas is the primary goal and tool for preventing irreversible biodiversity loss. However, the effectiveness of protected areas that target specific species has been questioned for some time because targeting key species for conservation may impair the integral regional pool of species diversity and phylogenetic and functional diversity are seldom considered. We assessed the efficacy of protected areas in China for the conservation of phylogenetic diversity based on the ranges and phylogenies of 2279 terrestrial vertebrates. Phylogenetic and taxonomic diversity were strongly and positively correlated, and only 12.1-43.8% of priority conservation areas are currently protected. However, the patterns and coverage of phylogenetic diversity were affected when weighted by species richness. These results indicated that in China, protected areas targeting high species richness protected phylogenetic diversity well overall but failed to do so in some regions with more unique or threatened communities (e.g., coastal areas of eastern China, where severely threatened avian communities were less protected). Our results suggest that the current distribution of protected areas could be improved, although most protected areas protect both taxonomic and phylogenetic diversity.

abstract.text: Establishing protected areas is the primary goal and tool for preventing irreversible biodiversity loss. However, the effectiveness of protected areas that target specific species has been questioned for some time because targeting key species for conservation may impair the integral regional pool of species diversity and phylogenetic and functional diversity are seldom considered. We assessed the efficacy of protected areas in China for the conservation of phylogenetic diversity based on the ranges and phylogenies of 2279 terrestrial vertebrates. Phylogenetic and taxonomic diversity were strongly and positively correlated, and only 12.1-43.8% of priority conservation areas are currently protected. However, the patterns and coverage of phylogenetic diversity were affected when weighted by species richness. These results indicated that in China, protected areas targeting high species richness protected phylogenetic diversity well overall but failed to do so in some regions with more unique or threatened communities (e.g., coastal areas of eastern China, where severely threatened avian communities were less protected). Our results suggest that the current distribution of protected areas could be improved, although most protected areas protect both taxonomic and phylogenetic diversity.

body_text.text: Resumen: El establecimiento deáreas protegidas es la meta y herramienta principal para prevenir una pérdida irreversible de la biodiversidad. Sin embargo, la efectividad de lasáreas protegidas que se enfocan en especies determinadas ha sido cuestionada durante algún tiempo, pues enfocarse en especies clave para la conservación puede perjudicar al pool regionalíntegro de diversidad de especies y rara vez se consideran la diversidad filogenética y funcional. Evaluamos la efectividad de lasáreas protegidas en China para la conservación de la diversidad filogenética con base en la extensión y la filogenia de 2279 vertebrados terrestres. La diversidad filogenética y la taxonómica estuvieron considerablemente correlacionadas, y sólo 12.1 -43.8% de lasáreas de conservación prioritarias están protegidas actualmente. Independientemente de esto, los patrones y coberturas de la diversidad filogenética se vieron afectados cuando se sopesaron con la riqueza de especies. Estos resultados indicaron que en China lasáreas protegidas que se enfocan en la riqueza alta de especies protegen bien a la diversidad filogenética en general pero fallaron en hacerlo en algunas regiones con comunidades másúnicas o amenazadas (p. ej.: lasáreas costeras del este de China, en donde las comunidades de aves bajo amenaza severa están menos protegidas). Nuestros resultados sugieren que la distribución actual deáreas protegidas podría mejorarse, aunque la mayoría de lasáreas protegidas protegen tanto a la diversidad taxonómica como a la filogenética.
Palabras Clave: características evolutivas, planeación de la conservación, puntos calientes, riqueza de especies, vacíos de conservación   :   ,  ,  ,  2279  ,  ,  ,  , , , , , , 12.1ß43.8% ,

The current use of biotic resources and rates of environmental disruption, as reported by the Millennium Ecosystem Assessment (2005) , has accelerated the loss of biodiversity, and this loss will eventually threaten the sustainability of human society. In response, many biodiversity conservation actions have been undertaken. Among these, establishment of protected areas (PAs) is probably most effective in protecting local and regional biodiversity (Rodrigues et al. 2004a; Chape et al. 2005) . By setting up areas free from serious human disturbance, PA systems aim to maintain habitats for species that require in situ or ex situ conservation, protect coexisting organisms, and maintain the original landscape. Designers of PAs try to ensure that biodiversity is well protected at all levels, including gene, species, phylogeny, and function. Current PA systems are designed to achieve these goals by protecting areas containing threatened species and fragile areas of ecological importance. Their locations, however, tend to be based primarily on taxonomic diversity, and designers seldom consider phylogenetic and functional diversity. In many cases, protocols to locate PAs are taxon based. That is, they focus, for example, on richness of targeted taxa and the presence of rare and threatened species. The Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF) and the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), for example, have collected millions of species records and have data on their distribution ranges, threat status, and other information that is required to inform these protocols. Most of the species-based protocols treat different taxa as equal entities, ignoring species' unique evolutionary status and functional traits (Faith 1992; HewettEmmett & Tashian 1996) . However, it is a species' evolutionary potential and intrinsic ecological value that matters for sustaining stable ecosystems. Species-based approaches tend to underrepresent rare and genetically distinct species and overrepresent widespread species (Brooks et al. 2006) . Under global climate change, the loss of phylogenetic diversity will induce the loss of future evolutionary options (Barker 2002) and alter species' interactions, which will eventually change the functioning and services of an ecosystem (Devictor et al. 2010) . Therefore, the call to consider evolutionary history and ecological functions in conservation planning is growing.

Conservation scientists have explored the relationship between taxonomic (TD), phylogenetic (PD), and functional (FD) diversity and introduced the latter two dimensions to PA design (e.g., Flynn et al. 2011; Guilhaumon et al. 2015; Lindenmayer et al. 2015) . The PD of sites, communities, and regions has been accumulated by recording the evolutionary signals of species, and these signals have been weighted based on the number of descendants from the same ancestor, abundance, or range or threat status to prioritize areas that provide the greatest conservation benefits (Cadotte & Davies 2016) . Phylogenetic relationships indicate phenotypic and ecological similarities, such that PD could be a measure of evolutionary history as well as an approximation of FD (Faith 2013) (but see Devictor et al. [2010] and Kelly et al. [2014] ). A criticism is that PD has a strong positive correlation with species richness, such that PD is not necessary when species-richness hotspots are fully covered by PAs (Rodrigues et al. 2011) . However, results of recent studies still support the idea that PD improves conservation planning by providing additional information that cannot be inferred from species richness (Hartmann & Andre 2013) or the presence of threatened species (Hidasi-Neto et al. 2013) .

It is common that species and sites in need of protection fall outside PAs. Fortunately, gaps between diversity priorities and existing PAs can be identified readily by overlaying maps of PAs with maps of the distributions of threatened species and regions in geographic information systems (Scott et al. 1993) . Based on such a gap analysis, many researchers have suggested amendments to PA systems for various taxa at local, regional, and global levels (e.g., Powell et al. 2000; Rodrigues et al. 2004a; Wen et al. 2015) . However, the mismatch between contemporary PA design and diversity priorities is still considerable (Rodrigues et al. 2004b) . For example, PA systems in Africa are unbalanced in favor of protecting vegetation types (van Breugel et al. 2015) . The PA systems in China and the United States also miss multiple potential or actual distributions of vulnerable species (Jenkins et al. 2015; Wen et al. 2015) . And, the PA network in Brazil's Cerrado does not cover the higher-than-expected PD and FD sites for bats and nonflying mammals (Carvalho et al. 2010) . Contemporary methods of PA design produce farfrom-optimal solutions; a more comprehensive PA planning process that considers more groups of species, evolutionary processes, and functional traits is still needed.

Through Aichi Biodiversity Target 11, multiple countries have committed to building global PA systems that cover at least 17% of each country's terrestrial biome by 2020 (Juffe-Bignoli et al. 2014) . Currently, official PAs are expanding quickly and have reached about 12.5% of Earth's land surface, but they may not achieve conservation goals because of inappropriate and insufficient management (Watson et al. 2014) . Lack of PA-coverage assessment in terms of evolutionary potential and functional traits may further impede the effectiveness of conservation practices. In the last decade in China, number of populations of over 65% of highly threatened animals have decreased (Gu et al. 2015) , despite the increase in PAs. A likely reason for this is the gap between existing PAs and future priorities. We considered hotspots of taxonomic and phylogenetic diversity and the conservation priorities of terrestrial vertebrates in China with the objective of assessing the conservation efficacy of current PA systems. It is difficult to identify and deduce suitable functional traits to analyze the FD for many species. We assumed, therefore, that PD represents FD to some extent (Faith 2013) . We overlaid the range maps of species (n = 2279) in 4 terrestrial vertebrate classes with PAs in China to determine whether at a regional scale information on phylogenetic diversity usefully supplements information on taxonomic diversity and the effectiveness of the current Chinese PA systems in protecting phylogenetic diversity and evolutionary distinctiveness.

Mainland China spans 18-53 o N and 73−134 o E (Fig. 1) . It is mostly temperate and contains the intersection of the Palearctic and Oriental regions. Its biomes are strongly affected by the uplift of the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau and its subsequent effects (Lei et al. 2014; Wu et al. 2017) . We divided China (excluding Taiwan because of the lack of exact PA data) into 15,388, 15 × 15 minute (490-725 km 2 ) cells as operating units and plotted species ranges on them. At this resolution, many cells could cover 1 or 2 PAs and areas adjacent to the PAs. Because PAs protect populations better than unprotected areas, they could be the source of species diffusing and benefit communities in adjacent areas. We assumed spatial homogeneity in one cell.

The IUCN (2014) created global range maps for amphibians, reptiles (not comprehensive), and mammals. BirdLife International (2016) did the same for birds. We overlaid these maps on a map of China and produced presence-absence matrices of cells, class by class (Amphibia 359 species, Reptilia 216, Aves 1245, and Mammalia 569). Only 216 species of reptiles from IUCN range maps were counted, which is far fewer than the number listed by Zhao et al. (2000) , in which China has 412 reptile species. Therefore, we combined the reptile presenceabsence matrix with records from GBIF (2016). The distribution information of orders in Reptilia was unbalanced. Distribution information of Squamata were more comprehensive than those of Testudines and Crocodilia. Moreover, given that Reptilia is a paraphyletic group, we only included data on Squamata in our analyses (348 species).

We based our PD diversity calculations on previously published phylogenies: amphibians, Isaac et al. 2012; mammals, Bininda-Emonds et al. 2007; Squamata, Pyron et al. 2013; and birds, Jetz et al. (2014) . The Squamata supertree included 4161 species even though this clade contains >9000 species globally. To our knowledge, it is the most comprehensive tree available for Squamata. We downloaded 5000 trees from birdtree.org, which is based on data from Jetz et al. (2014) , and summarized the phylogeny of birds with TreeAnnotator. We checked the synonyms for species not in the phylogenies, and the final count was 305 amphibians, 199 reptiles, 1235 birds, and 540 mammals for analysis.

We calculated phylogenetic diversity and evolutionary distinctiveness following the methods described below. First, we computed PD sum (Faith's [1992] PD), which is the sum of the branch length of all species in one site and measures total evolutionary history (Faith 1992) . We extracted evolutionary distinctiveness scores (ED) from the phylogenies to describe species uniqueness (Isaac et al. 2007) . Relict species tend to have higher ED scores, implying they are more phylogenetically specialized than those that radiated recently. However, the length of evolutionary history does not predict the probability of future phylogenetic loss. Species with small range sizes compared with those that are widely distributed are probably much more vulnerable because their habitats may vanish under global climate change (Cadotte & Davies 2010) . Therefore, we divided species' ED by their own and their subtending species' global distribution areas (from IUCN) to get biogeographically weighted ED (BED) (Cadotte & Davies 2010). Besides distribution ranges, actual population sizes and dynamics also indicate extinction risk. We followed Issac (2007) to weight ED by threat status, referred to as evolutionary distinct and globally endangered (EDGE). We converted the IUCN threat status categories to numbers: 0, least concern = 0; 1, near threatened and conservation dependent; 2, vulnerable; 3, endangered; and 4, critically endangered. Data deficient has no value in Isaac's framework, but we assigned 1 to the category because more attention should be paid to species for which there are no data. Species in the top 25% of rankings of BED and EDGE were considered species at high risk of extinction. Regions where the richness of species with top-ranking BED and EDGE (BED R and EDGE R ) is high should be conservation priorities. We also calculated BED (BED C ) and EDGE (EDGE C ) of species in each grid to evaluate the overall vulnerability patterns.

After weighting richness, the phylogenetic diversity and evolutionary distinctiveness is expected to deviate from the original values in some regions. Forest et al. (2007) proposed that such regions be priorities for conservation because species they represent unique evolutionary histories and traits. We randomized the species compositions of cells 999 times while maintaining their richness and calculated the standard effect size (SES) of PD sum (PD ses ) and SES of EDGE C (EDGE ses ) according to
EQUATION

eq_spans.raw_str: SES = obs − Mean rand SD rand ,

body_text.text: where, for example, obs is the original PD sum value of cells; mean rand and SD rand are the average and standard deviation of new PD sum values based on the randomizations; and SES is PD ses . The values for EDGE ses were calculated in the same way. Regions with an evolutionary history value larger than expected have positive PD ses and regions subject to more severe threat than expected have a positive EDGE ses . Because of a lack of required information, we calculated only species richness, ED R (species richness of high ED), PD sum , and PD ses for reptiles.

We used simple correlations to detect whether TD and PD coincide with each other. We divided PD measures into three groups. The first group included BED R , EDGE R , and ED R , and it indicated whether total species richness coincided with the richness of species at high risk.

We computed Kendall's τ between species richness and these two indices. The second group contained PD sum , BED C , and EDGE C, and the third group contained PD ses and EDGE ses . These second and third groups indicate whether taxonomic richness predicted original and relative PD. We computed Pearson's r between species richness and those indices.

We generated distribution maps of protected areas in We used the ratio of PD hotspots covered by nature reserves and their locations to assess the effectiveness of the PA system for maintaining PD. We extracted cells of conservation priority and overlaid PA maps. According to the different indices described above, we obtained different priority criteria: cells in the top quartile for species richness, EDGE R , BED R , PD sum , EDGE C , and BED C (cells with value 0 were excluded) and cells with PD ses or EDGE ses >1.28 (meaning the significance level of observed values greater than expected [0.1]). We assumed that cells with centers within the boundaries of PAs would maintain their PD in the future. Our analyses were conducted in the R platform (R Core Team 2015), and the PD indices were calculated using the PhyloMeasures package (Tsirogiannis & Sandel 2015) and the R package Picante (Kembel et al. 2010) .

Species richness, Faith's PD (PD sum ), richness of species at risk (EDGE R and BED R ), and cumulated PD (EDGE C and BED C ) had similar patterns of distribution for all four clades (Fig. 2) . All indices above for birds and mammals had their highest values in the Hengduan Mountains and values gradually decreased as distance from this region increased ( Fig. 2c, d ). The indices for amphibians and reptiles peaked mainly in the Wuyi Mountains, Nanling Mountains, and the east end of the Yungui Plateau (Figs.  2a-b ). However, amphibians in northeast China, reptiles in central China, and birds in southeast China all had higher phylogenetic diversity (high PD ses ) than expected, although these regions were not richness hotspots (Figs.  2a-c) . The EDGE ses showed that communities with more severe losses than expected in evolutionary distinctiveness were distributed along coastal areas for birds and the

; phylogenetic diversity (PD sum ); and standard effect size of PD sum (PD ses ). southern part of the Himalayas and western Gobi Desert for mammals. For birds and mammals, conservation priorities indicated by species richness were quite different from those indicated by EDGE ses (Fig. 2c-d ).
body_text.section: Figure 2. Taxonomic and phylogenetic diversity patterns of (a) amphibians, (b) reptiles, (c) birds, and (d) mammals in China relative to species richness; richness of species with high evolutionary distinct and globally endangered (EDGE) scores (EDGE R ); cumulated EDGE in cells (EDGE C ,); standard effect size of EDGE C (EDGE ses ); richness of species with high evolutionary distinctiveness scores (ED R ); richness of species with biogeographically weighted ED R scores (BED R ); cumulated BED R in cells (BED C )

body_text.text: Simple correlations confirmed similarity among patterns of the diversity indices (Table 1) . Results not weighted by species richness supported the criticism that PD provides no more information than TD provides. Species richness of terrestrial vertebrate clades had a strong positive correlation with EDGE R , PD sum , and EDGE C (mean correlation coefficient = 0.885 [SD 0.134] ). This indicated that these three indices provided little more information than species richness provided. The PA systems targeting species richness, therefore, protected PD and hotspots of phylogenetically endangered species equally well. The correlations of richness against BED R and BED C ranged from 0.160 to 0.614 (mean = 0.374 [SD 0.159]). Species richness was not a good predictor for phylogenetic endemism. However, regions with high BED R and BED C were patchily distributed and most were covered by hotspots of species richness. This means total evolutionary history, phylogenetic endemism, or phylogenetic distinctiveness would be protected if the PA fully covered areas of high species richness. However, null models decoupled richness and PD indicators. The SEZ of PD indicators was weak or even negatively related to richness (Table 1) . Regions with low biodiversity could have much higher PD than expected or be under more serious threat.
body_text.section: Figure 2. Taxonomic and phylogenetic diversity patterns of (a) amphibians, (b) reptiles, (c) birds, and (d) mammals in China relative to species richness; richness of species with high evolutionary distinct and globally endangered (EDGE) scores (EDGE R ); cumulated EDGE in cells (EDGE C ,); standard effect size of EDGE C (EDGE ses ); richness of species with high evolutionary distinctiveness scores (ED R ); richness of species with biogeographically weighted ED R scores (BED R ); cumulated BED R in cells (BED C )

body_text.text: According to the priority criteria, 27 maps of priority areas were generated (8 for amphibians, 4 for reptiles, 8 for birds, and 7 for mammals ( Fig. 3) . Of these maps, 18 had over 2500 cells of high priority (Table 2) . They were generally the maps of high species richness, high richness of phylogenetically endangered and endemic species, and high total PD, and those maps showed similar distribution patterns of priority areas. A total of 36.6% (SD 3.4) of the cells in the 18 maps overlapped with existing PAs. In comparison, the maps of PD ses and EDGE ses for terrestrial vertebrates, except birds, mostly had <200 cells with values >1.28 (Table 2) . This implies that very few sites in China had greater phylogenetic diversity or were under greater threat than expected by their richness. The average percentage of PA coverage was 25.7 % (SD 7.2).
body_text.section: Figure 2. Taxonomic and phylogenetic diversity patterns of (a) amphibians, (b) reptiles, (c) birds, and (d) mammals in China relative to species richness; richness of species with high evolutionary distinct and globally endangered (EDGE) scores (EDGE R ); cumulated EDGE in cells (EDGE C ,); standard effect size of EDGE C (EDGE ses ); richness of species with high evolutionary distinctiveness scores (ED R ); richness of species with biogeographically weighted ED R scores (BED R ); cumulated BED R in cells (BED C )

body_text.text: Protecting PD is believed to be important for prospective conservation practices. We identified patterns of PD for terrestrial vertebrates in China and the extent to which they were protected by PA systems. Total PD had a strong positive correlation with species richness. Total phylogenetic diversity hotspots for birds and mammals occurred mainly in southwest China and those of amphibians and reptiles occurred mainly in south China. The richness patterns of phylogenetically fragile species were similar to those of the total phylogenetic diversity. Patterns of phylogenetically fragile communities diverged from those of phylogenetic diversity, which would be useful information for conservation planning. About one-third of cells identified as priorities by PD indices overlapped with provincial and national PAs.

Phylogenetic-diversity indices could complement TD indices in conservation planning. Criticisms have been made that when species richness is well conserved, preservation of phylogenetic diversity is not needed, and, indeed, hotspots of species richness are usually hotspots of phylogenetic diversity (Sechrest et al. 2002; Rodrigues et al. 2005) . However, reasons for applying PD are also clear. First, PD values for a given subset of species may deviate from expected values because of the powercurve relationship between PD and richness (Faith 2013) . However, in our analyses all phylogenetic diversity measures that involved the accumulation of species richness had strong positive linear relationships with species richness. We did not observe curvilinear relationships for the indices we applied. Second, species richness is not the only index that can be used to quantify biological value for conservation. In our study, PD ses distinguished richness hotspots with high PD from richness coldspots with relatively high PD. In regions with high PD and high richness, only phylogenetically clumped extinctions could strongly diminish PD (Faith 2013) . In regions with high PD but low species richness, each species contains more information on evolutionary processes and even functional traits. Richness losses there may lead to a rapid decline in local ecological services (Kareiva & Marvier 2003) . Such coldspots also require attention in conservation planning.
body_text.section: Phylogenetic Diversity as a Useful Complement to Taxonomic Diversity

body_text.text: We found that 12.1-43.8% of hotspot cells, indicated by different PD indices, intersected PAs. And, 28.5% cells (4,386 cells out of 15,388) in Mainland China intersected with PAs. However, according to MEPC, only about 15.4% of the terrestrial area of Mainland China is protected. The overestimation is the result of deviations between PAs and cells. Many cells were not fully covered by the PAs. If we roughly take the deviation into account (the percentage of hotspot cells intersecting PAs multiplied by the ratio between actual areas and cells covered by PAs), only 6.5-23.7% of the hotspot areas are covered by PAs. This means far fewer hotspots are under the protection of national PAs. In China national PAs cover only a fraction of the most endangered animal hotspots: 10.9% for mammals, 1.13% for birds, and 7.26% for plants (Wen et al. 2015) . So, the efficiency of the PA system in China for conserving PD may not be too bad, but it is still far from satisfactory.
body_text.section: Coverage Efficiency of Chinese PA Systems

body_text.text: The maps of the diversity indices revealed inconsistencies that might be useful for improving the design of the Chinese PA system. First, priority areas were mainly distributed in mountainous regions; hotspots of birds and mammals were in the Hengduan Mountains (Fig. 3c, d ) and those of amphibians and reptiles in the Nanling and Wuyi Mountains (Figs. 3a-b) . For this reason, nature reserves that protect birds and mammals would not cover amphibians and reptiles very well. Biodiversity patterns of other taxa, such as insects and plants, may also differ from the 4 vertebrate groups (Wolters et al. 2006) . Distributions of PAs, especially national and provincial ones, should be balanced between hotspots of different taxa.
body_text.section: Gaps and Inconsistencies between PAs and Conservation Priorities

body_text.text: Second, regions of great species richness did not coincide with regions of higher phylogenetic diversity than expected. Protected areas designed in regions with low TD but high PD (such as the Qingling Mountains for amphibians and Lower Yangtze Region for birds) (Fig. 2) should cause concern because slight declines in species there may result in considerable PD losses and even functional damage to local ecosystems. Similarly, some regions were not hotspots of most phylogenetically threatened species. However, they were more severely threatened than expected, including the east and south coast and northeast China which have many wetlands that are important for waterbirds (Fig. 2) . This indicates species with high threat status may occupy larger percentages of communities in those areas than in other regions. These regions should also receive high conservation priority because communities there are probably more vulnerable to anthropogenic interference. When funds are limited, trade-offs should be made between hotspots of vulnerable species and regions containing vulnerable communities.
body_text.section: Gaps and Inconsistencies between PAs and Conservation Priorities

body_text.text: Third, as in many other countries, the distribution of PAs is unbalanced (Watson et al. 2014) . In China coverage by nature reserves is greater in cold and barren regions, such as the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau, whereas warm and productive regions are relatively poorly covered (Wen et al. 2015) . For example, the Qiangtang Nature Reserve for Tibetan Antelope (Pantholops hodgsonii), wild donkey (Equus kiang), and Przewalski's gazelle (Procapra przewalskii) covers over 250,000 km 2 and makes up about 20% of the total area of all national and provincial reserves. The mountain regions of southwest China and the wetlands of east China are among the top 25 global conservation priorities (Myers et al. 2000) and important habitats for water birds (BirdLife International 2017). They also hold the highest phylogenetic diversity and contain highly phylogenetically threatened communities of birds. However, nature reserves in these regions are small and patchy, which means habitat is fragmented. Habitat fragmentation would easily cause biodiversity loss (Wilson et al. 2016) , so that large PAs are better than many small ones. However, PA designs result not only from scientific but also political and economic choices. It is impractical to establish giant protected areas in the eastern half of China because of the dense human population and the pressing need for land for agriculture and industry. Preserving many small but well-managed and diversified landscapes may be an acceptable choice.
body_text.section: Gaps and Inconsistencies between PAs and Conservation Priorities

body_text.text: Gaps and weaknesses in contemporary conservation practices could be examined by comparing patterns of taxonomic and phylogenetic diversity and the placement of protected areas. Phylogenetic diversity could be used to identify regions with longer evolutionary histories and communities under severe threat. Even if such sites are not hotspots of species richness, they may require more nature reserves and funds because of their importance in maintaining future evolutionary potential and local ecosystem services.
body_text.section: Gaps and Inconsistencies between PAs and Conservation Priorities

body_text.text: Conservation BiologyVolume 32, No. 2, 2018

FIGREF0.text: Topographic map of China and current distributions of national and provincial nature reserves. Conservation Biology Volume 32, No. 2, 2018

FIGREF1.text: Priority areas for conservation of (a) amphibians, (b) reptiles, (c) birds, and (d) mammals indicated by 9 taxonomic and phylogenetic diversity indices (red, priority areas; white lines, boundaries of protected areas; white points, nature reserves based only on georeferenced location). Abbreviations defined in legend ofFig. 2.

FIGREF2.text: The number of cells indicated by species richness and phylogenetic indices as conservation priorities of 4 animal classes (all) and the number and percentage of those priority conservation cells within or overlapping current protected areas of China (covered

TABREF0.text: China based the World Database on Protected Areas (WDPA) (2015) and the National Nature Reserve Lists of China (2014) from the Ministry of Environmental Protection of the People's Republic of China (MEPC) (2015).
TABREF0.content:
According to the MEPC, in 2014, the PA systems of China
contained 428 national, 858 provincial, and 1443 county
nature reserves. We excluded county reserves from our
analysis because their function as nature reserves is of-
ten undermined by funding deficiencies and poor man-
agement. The maps of provincial and national nature
reserves were extracted if their name was in both the
WDPA and MEPC lists. For nature reserves on only MEPC
lists, we used only their georeferenced locations. We also
excluded PAs established to protect fossils or geological
relics. The total number of nature reserves was 1200, and
they covered 28.5% of cells (4,386 cells out of 15,388) in
Mainland China.

a Abbreviations: EDGE R , richness of species with high evolutionarily
distinct and globally endangered (EDGE) scores; BED R , richness of
species with biogeographically weighted evolutionary distinctiveness
(ED) scores; ED R , richness of species with high ED scores; PD sum ,
phylogenetic diversity; EDGE C , cumulated EDGE in cells; BED C , cu-
mulated BED in cells; PD ses , standard effect size of PD sum ; EDGE ses ,
standard effect size of EDGE C . b Only the coefficients between species richness and ED R , PD sum , and
PD ses were calculated.

TABREF2.text: Use of cells with the top quartile of species richness, EDGE R , BED R , PD sum , EDGE C, and BED C and cells with PD ses or EDGE ses >1.28 were the 2 identified areas for conservation that protected the greatest species richness and phylogenetic diversity. A dash means the corresponding indices were not calculated. Abbreviations of indices are defined in a footnote of Table 1.
